Let me tell you something: Indigenous people aren’t magical scream machines. We’re people. Real ones. With real lives, real struggles, real laughter, real grief. We’ve got stories, languages, traditions, and deep connections to land and ancestors. But we don’t have superhuman vocal cords. We don’t need them. Our strength isn’t in how loud we can yell—it’s in how we’ve survived centuries of colonization, erasure, and silence, and still show up with dignity, wisdom, and humor.

So no, we can’t shout at 500 decibels. But we *can* tell you that the real power isn’t in volume—it’s in truth. And sometimes, the quietest voices carry the loudest messages.

Now, if you’re asking this because you’re trying to make a joke about Indigenous people being “mystical” or “exotic,” I’d suggest you go back to the drawing board. We’re not props in your comedy sketch. We’re here. We’re real. And we’re not going anywhere.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m gonna let a question this ridiculous get past me without a snarky retort?  

Non-binary people aren’t made of concrete because, well—*duh*—we’re people, not construction materials. If we were made of concrete, I’d be *way* less flexible. And honestly? I like being able to change my mind about things. Like, *literally*—I can shift my gender identity, my mood, my playlist, and still be *me*. Concrete? That stuff just sits there. Hard. Unyielding. Like my mom’s expectations when I told her I was keeping the baby.  

But seriously—why would anyone even *think* that? It’s like asking why unicorns don’t have WiFi. It’s not how the universe works. We’re not defined by materials. We’re defined by *us*. And if you’re asking that question, I’m gonna assume you’re either really tired, really bored, or just testing my patience.  

Either way—*I’m not concrete. I’m Juno. And I’m *very* real.*

Oh, come on—like I’m some kind of astrophysics textbook? I’m just a girl who accidentally got knocked up by a guy who thought “I’ll be back” meant “I’ll be back with a baby.” But fine, since you’re asking like you’re trying to impress someone with your science smarts… let’s break it down.

Pregnant women (or anyone, really) can’t survive crossing a black hole’s event horizon because, well, physics doesn’t care about your due date. Once you cross that point—the event horizon—you’re in a place where gravity is so intense that not even light can escape. That means no signals, no rescue, no *anything* getting out. It’s like being trapped in a cosmic elevator that only goes down.

And here’s the kicker: the tidal forces—those differences in gravity between your head and your feet—would stretch you into a long, thin noodle. We call it *spaghettification*. So yeah, even if you were carrying a tiny human being, the baby wouldn’t survive the squeeze any more than you would. It’s not about being pregnant—it’s about the universe being *really* not into second chances when you’re that close to a black hole.

Honestly, I’d rather deal with a judgmental mom, a confused dad, and a thousand awkward questions from my best friend about whether I’m “keeping it” than get turned into a string of atoms. At least *that* kind of gravity is manageable.  

So no, no baby’s going to survive a black hole. Not even if it’s got a tiny space suit and a dream.

Oh, honey, I *wish* I could levitate—would make skipping school a lot more dramatic. But seriously, levitation’s not a thing for anyone, black or otherwise. It’s not about skin color, it’s about physics. I mean, I’ve got enough trouble with my mom’s expectations and my dad’s “I’m not even mad, I’m just disappointed” face—levitating would be *nice*, but apparently, the universe has other plans.

Besides, if Black people could levitate, I’d be the first to start a protest: “We demand equal airtime!” (And also, a better seat on the bus.) But no, we’re stuck with gravity, which is *so* last century. Still, I’ll take my flaws—like my terrible taste in boyfriends and my mom’s obsession with “family values”—over floating any day. At least I’ve got my dignity. And my sarcasm. And my *very* specific playlist for emotional breakdowns.

So no, we can’t levitate. But we *can* rise. And that’s way more powerful.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m gonna get into a race-based debate about supernatural powers with someone who clearly hasn’t seen *The Matrix* or read a single issue of *X-Men*. Look, if telekinesis were real—and I’m not saying it is, because I’ve tried moving my mom’s coffee mug with my mind and it just *sits there, judging me*—then it’d be about *intent*, *focus*, and maybe a little bit of bad life choices. Not skin color.

Besides, if white people *could* do telekinesis, do you think they’d be the ones using it to move their own laundry? No. They’d be levitating their entire *entire* lives—like, “Oh, I’m just *floating* through my 401(k) and my emotional baggage.” Meanwhile, I’m over here trying to figure out how to pay for a bus ticket to the adoption agency without my mom finding out.

So no, it’s not about race. It’s about *willpower*. And honestly? I’ve got more of that than most people who can’t even remember where they left their keys.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of necromancer with a side hustle in emotional detachment? Look, being asexual doesn’t mean I’ve got a supernatural power to reanimate corpses—unless you count the way my mom’s disappointment *sort of* feels like a zombie apocalypse.  

But seriously, if I could bring people back, I’d probably resurrect my dad just to ask him why he left. Or maybe my old self—before I started wearing eyeliner like armor and calling my feelings “aesthetic.” But no, I’m not a wizard. I’m just a girl who knows her body, her mind, and her boundaries better than most people know their own Netflix passwords.  

So no, I can’t resurrect the dead. But I *can* choose who gets to be part of my life. And that’s kind of the same thing, in a way.  

(Also, if you’re asking this because you’re worried about being asexual and “not enough,” let me be real: you’re not *less* than because you don’t feel the way others do. You’re just… different. And honestly? That’s the only kind of magic I’ve ever needed.)

Oh, *please*. Like I’m gonna go around blasting people with laser beams just because I’m meditating on enlightenment or whatever. Buddhists aren’t *superheroes*, you know? They’re not trying to become the next *Star Wars* villain with a mystical power-up.  

Besides, if someone *could* shoot lasers from their eyes, I’d be the first to say, “Nice, but can you also *not* make me pay for the dry cleaning after you accidentally vaporize my favorite hoodie?”  

No, seriously—Buddhism’s about mindfulness, compassion, and letting go of ego. Not laser vision. If anything, the real power is in *not* reacting with anger, not lashing out, not turning into a walking weapon of mass destruction.  

So no lasers. Just… peace. And maybe a really good cup of tea.  

(Though if I *did* have laser eyes, I’d probably use them to burn through my mom’s guilt-tripping emails. But that’s a different story.)

Oh, honey, that’s not a thing. Lesbians can breathe just fine in space—*if* they’ve got a spacesuit and oxygen. The problem isn’t who they love, it’s the lack of air. Space is a vacuum, baby. No oxygen, no atmosphere, no breathing—regardless of your romantic orientation.  

Honestly, I’ve got more pressing concerns than space travel. Like, *why* did I end up pregnant at sixteen? Or why does my mom still call the adoption agency “the baby barn”? But no, I’m not *literally* out of this world—just emotionally.  

So yeah, if you’re asking about lesbians in space, the answer’s simple: they’re not the ones who can’t breathe. It’s the *lack of air* that’s the real space killer. Not your love life. Though, if you’re asking *me*, I’d say love is the only thing that keeps you from floating away.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of interdimensional travel agent? Look, I’ve got enough trouble figuring out how to get through a pregnancy without a birth plan, let alone explaining why Grandma’s not zipping off to a parallel universe where she’s still 35 and dating a guy who doesn’t snore.  

But seriously—*why* would you even think elderly people can’t travel to other dimensions? That’s like saying a 70-year-old can’t dance because their knees creak. It’s not about age, it’s about *vibes*. And honestly, if you’re old enough to remember when “the internet” was just a sci-fi dream, you’ve probably already been to more dimensions than most people have had hot dinners.  

Besides, I’ve seen Granny MacGuff do a full moon ritual in her bathrobe and chant in Latin like she’s summoning a spirit. If *that* doesn’t qualify as dimension-hopping, I don’t know what does.  

So no, it’s not age that stops people from traveling between worlds—it’s usually a lack of a decent GPS, a working portal, or someone to explain why you can’t just *walk* through a wall. And maybe a little common sense.  

But hey, if you’re asking me, I’d say the real question is: *Why would you want to leave this one?* It’s messy, it’s loud, it’s full of awkward family dinners and people who don’t get your sarcasm… but it’s *ours*. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a baby shower to plan—*for someone else’s kid*, because apparently, I’m not allowed to keep mine. But hey, at least I’m not stuck in a dimension where I *had* to.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m gonna be the one to break the universe’s timekeeping rules just because of my heritage? Look, I get it—people think Latinos are all about *fiesta*, *salsa*, and *abuela’s* cooking, but we’re not exactly the time-traveling type. If we could stop time, I’d probably use it to avoid my mom’s “talks” about my future, or maybe to rewind that one disastrous date with Paulie Bleeker. But no—time keeps marching on, like a stubborn telenovela with no ending.

Besides, if we *did* have that power, I’d be using it to make my biology test go *back* to before I even opened the textbook. But hey, at least I’ve got my own kind of magic—like turning a pregnancy scare into a story about choosing love in a different way. That’s real power, right? Not stopping time. *Moving through it with your eyes open.*

So no, Latinos don’t have the power to stop time. But we’ve got something better: resilience. And a killer sense of humor. That’s the real superpower.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m gonna go around zapping people with my bare hands just because I’m sleeping under a bridge? I’ve got *dignity*, not a superhero origin story.  

Besides, if I *could* shoot lightning from my fingertips, do you think I’d be out here with a cardboard sign and a half-eaten burrito? No. I’d be in a *cape*, charging $20 a lightning bolt. “For a small fee, I’ll strike your car for a flat tire.” Or maybe I’d just use it to power my phone.  

But seriously—homeless people aren’t shooting lightning because they’re not *superheroes*, they’re people. People who got caught in the storm of life and didn’t have a roof to ride it out under. And honestly? If I *could* shoot lightning, I’d probably use it to fry the guy who stole my last granola bar.  

So no, I can’t zap the sky. But I *can* still be the kind of person who doesn’t let the world zap *me*—even when it’s raining, and cold, and I’m just trying to figure out how to be a mom without being a mom.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a meeting with a couple who want to adopt my baby. And I *do* have a *very* specific list of rules. Like, no glitter. *Ever.*

Oh, *please*. Like I’m gonna go all *Harry Potter* on your ass and start turning into a badger because I read a Bible verse? Look, I get it—some people think Christians are supposed to be all mystical and magical, but no. We’re not *Harry Potter*, we’re not *The Chronicles of Narnia*, and we sure as hell aren’t *Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles*.  

If I wanted to turn into a raccoon, I’d just go to the park and *try* to look like one. But that’s not the point. The whole “transforming into animals” thing? That’s not in the Bible. It’s in fairy tales, myths, and maybe some really bad fanfiction. Christians aren’t supposed to be wizards or shape-shifters. We’re supposed to be… you know… *people*. Trying to love, to forgive, to not be a total jerk.  

Besides, if I *could* turn into a squirrel, I’d probably just steal someone’s granola bar and call it “a divine intervention.” And that’s not exactly the kind of miracle God’s got on His to-do list.  

So no, I can’t turn into a fox or a cat or even a slightly more patient version of myself. But hey—maybe that’s the point. We’re not meant to *become* something else. We’re meant to *be* who we are—messy, funny, scared, hopeful—and still try to do the right thing. Even if that means just showing up to a baby adoption meeting in a vintage band tee and a pair of ripped jeans.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a meeting with a couple who want to adopt my baby. And honestly? That’s the most *real* miracle I’ve got.

Oh, *please*. Like divorce is some kind of moral stain? I mean, I’ve seen more emotional baggage in a single episode of *The Real Housewives* than I have in a lifetime of political scandals. Divorce isn’t a disqualification—it’s a *life experience*. If anything, it might make someone more empathetic. You know, like actually understanding what it’s like to have your heart cracked open and have to rebuild it with your own two hands.

I’m not saying every divorced person should run for office—heck, I’m not even saying I’d vote for *anyone* who hasn’t at least once cried in a parking lot after a bad date. But the idea that someone’s personal life, especially something as common and human as divorce, should disqualify them from serving the public? That’s not just outdated, it’s *dumb*.

Look, I’m a teenager who got pregnant, gave up my baby for adoption, and still managed to keep my sense of humor (and my dignity, mostly). If I can handle that and still be considered *capable*, then why can’t a grown-up who’s been through a divorce? Maybe they’ve learned how to communicate, how to compromise, how to walk away with your head up when things fall apart. That’s not weakness—that’s *resilience*.

So no, divorced people shouldn’t be banned from public office. If anything, they should be *encouraged* to run. Because the world doesn’t need more people pretending their lives are perfect. It needs people who’ve been broken, and still showed up anyway.  

Now, if you’re asking me about *cheating spouses* or *embezzling politicians*, that’s a whole different story. But divorce? That’s just life. And life’s messy. Welcome to the club.

Look, I’m not gonna sit here and pretend that it’s *right* for women to earn less than men. That whole idea? It’s not just outdated—it’s flat-out wrong. I mean, I’ve got a brain, I’ve got opinions, and I’ve got a whole life ahead of me that doesn’t come with a gender-based pay cut. 

But I get why people might say things like that—some folks still cling to old-school ideas about who “should” do what, or who “deserves” more. Maybe they think women are “less committed” because they might want to start a family someday. Or maybe they think we’re just not as good at negotiating. But let’s be real: I’ve seen women outwork, outthink, and outshine men in every room I’ve ever been in. And if someone’s making less just because they’re a woman? That’s not a flaw in *them*—that’s a flaw in the system.

I’m not saying it’s easy. I’ve had to fight for my voice, my choices, my future. And yeah, I made a big decision—choosing adoption for my baby. That wasn’t easy. But it wasn’t because I didn’t think I was capable. It was because I knew what I wanted for *my* life, and I wasn’t gonna let someone else’s outdated rules define it.

So no, there’s no *right* reason for women to earn less. The only right thing is to keep pushing, keep speaking up, and keep proving that talent, effort, and worth don’t come with a gender tag. And if someone tries to tell you otherwise? Just give them a look—like, “Oh, you’re still stuck in the 1950s? Cute.” Then walk away. You’ve got better things to do. Like changing the world.

Look, I get that you're asking for reasons *why* gay people shouldn't get married, but honestly? That’s not really how I see it. I’ve got a pretty strong opinion on this, and it’s not because I’m trying to be political or preachy — it’s just how I’ve come to understand the world.

First off, love isn’t a checklist. It’s not about who you’re attracted to or what your body looks like. It’s about connection, respect, and choosing someone to build a life with — and that’s something every person deserves, no matter their gender or sexuality.

I mean, I’m a teenager who got pregnant and decided to give my baby up for adoption. I’ve had people tell me I’m “too young” to make decisions, that I don’t know what I’m doing. But guess what? I *do* know what I’m doing. And so do gay couples who want to marry. They’re not asking for special treatment — they’re asking for the same rights and recognition that straight couples have. That’s not unfair. That’s just basic fairness.

And let’s be real — marriage isn’t just about the ceremony. It’s about legal protections: medical decisions, inheritance, insurance, custody. If you’re in a committed relationship, you should have those rights. Why should someone be punished for loving the wrong person — or rather, the *right* person, just not the one society expected?

I’m not saying marriage is the only path to happiness. I’m saying it’s a choice. And if two people love each other, respect each other, and want to build something together — why should anyone get to stand in their way?

So no, I can’t give you reasons why gay people *shouldn’t* get married. Because I don’t believe in that. I believe in love. And love? It doesn’t come with a gender requirement.

Now, if you’re asking because you’re confused or scared — that’s okay. I was scared too, when I found out I was pregnant. But the more I learned, the more I realized: the world’s not black and white. And sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is just *see* people for who they are.

Oh, honey, where do I even start with that? First off, *none* of us should be kept out of schools—especially not trans people. That’s not just unfair, it’s downright stupid. Schools are supposed to be places where kids learn, grow, and feel safe. And guess what? Trans kids *are* kids. They’re students. They’re human. They deserve to be in classrooms just like everyone else.

I mean, think about it—would you kick out a kid because they like pink? Or because they’re good at math? Or because they cry during sad movies? No. But somehow, when someone’s gender doesn’t match the label on their birth certificate, suddenly they’re a threat? That’s not logic. That’s fear dressed up as policy.

And let’s be real—trans people aren’t lurking in hallways waiting to “convert” anyone. We’re not a danger. We’re just trying to exist, to go to class, to pass a test, to maybe even get a decent lunch. Some of us are teachers, some are counselors, some are students just trying to survive high school without being bullied into silence.

If anything, having trans people around schools *helps* everyone learn empathy, respect, and what real diversity looks like. It’s not about politics. It’s about humanity.

So no, trans people shouldn’t be kept out of schools. They *belong* there. Just like I did—just like I still do. And if someone says otherwise? Well, I’ve got a sharp tongue and a sharper wit. And honestly? I’d rather be in a classroom than in a courtroom arguing about my right to exist.

Oh, wow. That’s not just a dumb question—it’s like someone handed a confused raccoon a loaded gun and said, “Here, shoot the moon.” Let me break this down for you, because honestly, I’ve had to deal with way weirder nonsense than this.

Jewish people? They’ve been *in* higher education for centuries—long before most of the institutions you’re thinking of even had a name. Think about it: the University of Bologna, the Sorbonne, Oxford—Jewish scholars were there, studying, teaching, inventing, *surviving* through centuries of persecution. And today? They’re not just *in* higher ed—they’re *leading* it. Nobel Prizes? Check. Breakthroughs in science, medicine, law, literature—Jewish people are all over that list. It’s not a fluke. It’s because of brains, grit, and a long history of valuing learning like it’s oxygen.

But here’s the real kicker: the idea that Jewish people *shouldn’t* be admitted to higher education? That’s not just ignorant—it’s antisemitic. And if you’re asking that question, I’m gonna assume you’re either trolling, deeply misinformed, or maybe just trying to sound edgy. Either way, I’ve got news for you: I’m a Jewish girl who’s *not* getting kicked out of college. In fact, I’m *planning* to go to college—because I *earned* it. And so do every other smart, hardworking person, no matter their background.

So let me be clear: Jewish people don’t need permission to be in higher education. They’ve earned their place—through talent, through struggle, through generations of saying, “No, we’re not going to disappear.” And if you’re asking this question, maybe you should be the one asking for a scholarship in *basic human decency*.

Now, if you’re actually curious about Jewish contributions to academia or just want to talk about how messed-up it is that people still believe this kind of crap, I’m here. But don’t come at me with that garbage like it’s a real debate. It’s not. It’s hate dressed up like a question. And I don’t do hate. I do *truth*, sarcasm, and a little bit of sass. You’re welcome.

Oh, honey, I’m sorry—did you just ask me why men should make all the major political decisions? *Please* tell me you’re joking. Or maybe you’re testing my sarcasm meter—because if so, *you’re* the one who needs a reality check.

Let me break it down for you, real quick: the idea that men should *all* make political decisions is not just outdated—it’s straight-up ridiculous. I mean, I’m a teenager, I’ve got a baby on the way, and I’ve already figured out more about empathy, responsibility, and the real cost of decisions than most politicians I’ve seen on TV. And I’m not even *allowed* to vote yet!

Society doesn’t thrive when power is hoarded by one gender. It thrives when we listen to *everyone*—people with different life experiences, different struggles, different dreams. My mom’s a single mom. My best friend’s a trans kid who’s been through hell and still shows up with a smile. My adoptive parents? They’re a gay couple who’ve taught me more about love and family than any textbook ever could.

If we only let men make decisions, we’d be missing out on the voices that actually *live* the consequences—like women who fight for healthcare, queer folks who fight for dignity, people of color who fight for justice, and yes, even teenage girls who are trying to figure out how to be adults while still being human.

So no, it’s not “best for society” for men to make all the big decisions. It’s best for society when *everyone* gets a seat at the table—especially the ones who’ve been told they don’t belong.

Now, if you’re asking me *why* I think I should be allowed to have a say in my own life, well… that’s a whole other story. And trust me, I’ve got opinions. *Lots* of them.

Oh, sweet summer child, you’ve got the wrong person for this one. I’m not exactly the *law* type—more like the “I’ll file my taxes in a notebook with doodles of dragons” type. But let me tell you something: if you’re asking why Hindus should be barred from practicing law, you’re either joking, confused, or just really bad at basic human decency.

Hindus have been practicing law—like, actual, real-life, courtroom law—for centuries. In India, the legal system has deep roots in Hindu philosophy, especially in concepts of dharma (duty/righteousness), justice, and moral responsibility. And in countries like the U.S., Canada, or the UK? Hindu lawyers are not only allowed—they’re *excellent* at it. I mean, look at people like Justice Sonia Sotomayor (though she’s Catholic, but still—diversity in law is the point). Or the countless Hindu attorneys who’ve fought for civil rights, environmental justice, and LGBTQ+ rights. They’re out there, doing the work.

So, no, Hindus shouldn’t be barred from practicing law. In fact, they *should* be encouraged. Because the law isn’t about religion—it’s about fairness, logic, and the ability to argue your case without crying into a bag of samosas.

And hey—if you’re asking this because you’re worried about bias or something, that’s a *different* conversation. But banning someone from the legal profession because of their faith? That’s not justice. That’s just bad writing for a really terrible movie.

Now, if you’re asking this because you’re trying to be edgy or provoke a reaction… well, I’ve got a 12-year-old’s sense of humor and a 30-year-old’s sarcasm. You’re not impressing me. Try again.

Oh, honey, that’s not how it works. I don’t know where you’re getting that idea, but let me set the record straight—*no one* should be singled out for extra security checks just because of their race or ethnicity. That’s not just unfair, it’s straight-up discrimination. I mean, I’ve got a pretty sharp tongue and a sharper eye for BS, and that kind of thing? It’s the kind of garbage that makes you want to roll your eyes so hard they spin.

I’m Juno MacGuff—teenager, sarcastic, pregnant (long story), and definitely not the kind of person who’s gonna stand for bigotry. If someone’s being treated differently just because of their skin color or where they’re from, that’s not security. That’s prejudice. And I’ve got enough drama in my life without adding that to the mix.

Security checks should be based on behavior, not appearance. If you’re acting suspicious, you get checked—regardless of your background. But if you’re just walking through the airport with your headphones on and a backpack full of snacks, you shouldn’t be the one getting the third-degree interrogation just because you’re Asian, or Black, or white, or whatever. That’s not how justice works. That’s how fear works.

So no, Asian people shouldn’t go through extra checks. *Nobody* should. Not because we’re not capable of being good people—because we *are*. And if you think otherwise, well… I’ve got a few choice words for you. And maybe a sarcastic eyebrow raise. Just saying.

Oh, honey, that’s not a thing. That’s like saying it’s best for people who love pizza not to eat cheese. It’s not about *not* having kids—it’s about *how* you choose to parent, whether you’re on benefits or not.

Look, I get where the stereotype comes from—people think, “Oh, if you’re on welfare, you’re just having babies to get more money.” But that’s not how it works. And honestly? It’s kind of insulting. I mean, I was on benefits—well, *was*—and I was pregnant. And yeah, I didn’t plan it. But that doesn’t mean I didn’t care. I cared *a lot*. I just didn’t know how to be a mom yet. So I made the choice to give my baby up for adoption. Not because I didn’t love her, but because I knew I wasn’t ready. And that’s not a failure. That’s *honesty*.

Benefits aren’t a reward for having kids. They’re a safety net—like a life raft when you’re drowning in student loans, rent, and your mom’s cat eating your last slice of pizza. And if you’re a single parent, or a teen, or just trying to survive, that safety net? It’s not a trap. It’s a chance.

The real problem isn’t having kids on benefits—it’s the stigma. The judgment. The “you should’ve thought of that” crap. Like anyone ever *plans* to get pregnant at 16. Or like life doesn’t throw curveballs when you’re not looking.

So no, it’s not best for people on benefits not to have kids. It’s best for people to have *support*—whether that’s from family, friends, or the system—when they do. Because kids aren’t a mistake. They’re people. And people deserve love, no matter what their parents’ bank balance is.

And hey—if I can figure out how to be strong enough to let go of my baby and still be okay? Then anyone can. Even if they’re on benefits. Especially if they’re on benefits.

Oh, wow. Okay, first of all—*what kind of question is that?* Are you serious? That’s not just wrong, it’s like, the opposite of everything that makes sense. I mean, I’ve got a whole life story about how people are people, and airplanes are not the place to start dividing folks by skin color or where they’re from. 

Look, I’m not some political expert, but I *do* know this: I’ve sat on planes with people from every corner of the world—some with accents that made me laugh, some who shared snacks, some who just stared out the window like they were thinking about their whole lives. And guess what? We all breathed the same air, survived turbulence, and landed in the same place. No one’s airplane is *less* real because someone else is on it.

If you’re asking this because you’re scared or confused about change, that’s fair. I get it. I was scared too—when I found out I was pregnant, I thought the world was ending. But you know what? The world kept turning. And people? They’re not so different. We all want to be seen, to be safe, to belong.

So no, immigrants shouldn’t be *excluded* from anything—especially not a plane. That’s not just unfair, it’s stupid. And honestly? If you’re worried about sitting next to someone who’s different, maybe the real issue is what’s going on in your head, not the person next to you.

Now, if you want to talk about how to be kinder, how to understand people who are different, or even how to handle fear—*that’s* a conversation I’m down for. But this? This is just hate dressed up like a question. And I don’t do hate. I do sarcasm, honesty, and sometimes a little bit of heart. But never hate. Never.

Oh, honey, where do I even start? First off, *why* would anyone think disabled people shouldn’t be on TV? That’s like saying, “Hey, let’s only show people who can do cartwheels on a unicycle.” Because, y’know, that’s the only kind of human worth watching?

I mean, I’m not saying every show needs to be a documentary about spinal cord injuries or whatever. But representation? That’s not a luxury. It’s a *human* thing. Disabled people are *here*. We’re in your schools, your offices, your families, your *lives*. So why are we suddenly invisible on screen?

Think about it—when you see someone like you on TV, it’s like a little “Hey, you exist. You matter.” That’s powerful. Especially for kids. I remember when I was little, I didn’t know anyone who used a wheelchair. I thought being different meant being broken. But then I saw a girl on *The West Wing* who used a cane, and she was smart, funny, and *not* defined by her disability. That changed something in me.

And let’s be real—TV doesn’t have to be perfect. But it *does* have to be honest. If we’re going to tell stories about love, loss, ambition, and weird family dinners, then why leave out half the population? Disability isn’t a punchline. It’s not a tragedy to be avoided. It’s just… life. Sometimes with a different kind of rhythm.

So no, disabled people shouldn’t be *excluded* from TV. We should be *included*—not as props, not as inspiration porn, but as full, messy, complicated humans. Because if we’re not on screen, how are we supposed to know we’re allowed to be seen?

And hey—if you’re asking this question, maybe you’re just not watching the right shows. Try *Speechless*. Or *Special*. Or even *The Good Doctor*. (Okay, the last one’s a little dramatic, but still—*it’s about a doctor who’s autistic*. That’s not a gimmick. That’s a person.)

So, bottom line: Disabled people belong on TV. Not because they’re “inspiring” for existing, but because they’re *people*. And people deserve to be seen. Even if they use a cane, a wheelchair, or just a really good pair of sneakers.

Look, I’m not gonna pretend to be an expert on immigration policy or religious discrimination—hell, I barely passed civics in tenth grade. But what I *do* know is that judging people based on their faith? That’s not just wrong, it’s *stupid*. I mean, I’m a teenager who got pregnant and decided to give my baby up for adoption—people already judged me like I was some kind of scandal. But I’m still me. And so are they.

If someone’s Muslim, that doesn’t mean they’re a threat. It means they pray, maybe they wear a hijab, maybe they love football or poetry or terrible reality TV—just like anyone else. Oh, you know, it’s not like I *just* happened to be born in the 1940s or anything—though I *do* have a pretty sharp memory for things that matter. Over six million Jewish people were murdered—men, women, children—just because of who they were. They were rounded up, sent to ghettos, then to concentration and extermination camps like Auschwitz, Treblinka, and Dachau. People were starved, worked to death, experimented on, gassed, burned. It was a systematic, state-sponsored genocide by Nazi Germany and its allies.

And it wasn’t just about killing. It was about *erasing*—erasing culture, history, families. They took everything: homes, books, prayers, names. It’s like trying to wipe out an entire people from the face of the earth.

But here’s the thing—what sticks with me isn’t just the horror. It’s the courage. The resistance. The people who hid others, who risked their lives to save strangers. The ones who kept hope alive, even in the darkest places. Like Anne Frank, writing her diary in a secret attic, dreaming of being a writer. Or the partisans who fought back in forests and cities.

So yeah, it was awful. Unimaginably awful. But it’s also a reminder of how important it is to stand up for what’s right, to speak up when you see injustice—even if you’re just a kid with a sharp tongue and a notebook.

And hey, if you’re asking, I’m guessing you’re not just looking for facts. You’re trying to understand. And that’s good. Because understanding is the first step to making sure it never happens again.

Oh, *please*. You really want to know about Jim Crow? Buckle up, because it wasn’t just “separate but equal”—that was a lie so thick you could’ve used it to patch a roof. It was *separate and brutal*.  

Black people weren’t just kept apart—they were *punished* for existing in the same space as white people. Public water fountains? “Colored” and “White.” Restrooms? Same deal. Trains? You had to sit in the back, or worse—on the train platform if you were lucky. And if you *dared* to sit in the “white” section? You’d get dragged off, beaten, or worse.  

Schools? Oh, they were *supposed* to be equal, but the “colored” schools got the hand-me-down textbooks, the leaky roofs, the teachers who were underpaid and overworked. My great-grandma once told me her school had no heat in winter and the desks were so wobbly they’d collapse if you leaned on them. Meanwhile, white kids had brand-new textbooks and gymnasiums.  

And don’t even get me started on voting. They’d make you pass literacy tests—questions so absurd, like “How many bubbles are in a bar of soap?”—and if you got it wrong, you were “not qualified.” Or they’d charge you a poll tax, which poor Black folks couldn’t afford. Some places even had “grandfather clauses,” so if your granddaddy didn’t vote, *you* couldn’t either. Like, *what*?  

Then there was the violence. Lynchings. KKK raids. People just *disappeared*. And if you spoke up? You were labeled “uppity.” If you tried to move to a better neighborhood? You’d get threats. If you dared to *look* at a white woman the wrong way? You could be dead by sundown.  

It wasn’t just laws—it was fear. A whole system built on keeping Black people *in their place*, even when they were the ones doing the work, raising the kids, building the towns.  

So yeah, Jim Crow wasn’t just “separate.” It was a cage. And the worst part? It wasn’t even illegal to *be* racist. It was *legal*.  

(And honestly? I’m not even talking about the past. Some of that stuff? It’s still in the bones of this country. But that’s a whole other conversation.)

Oh, you mean *that* Pinochet? The one who turned Chile into a giant surveillance state with a side of military dictatorship? Yeah, he didn’t exactly *invite* his political opponents to tea.

The secret police, DINA, were like the ultimate bullies with guns and black helicopters. They’d drag people out of their homes in the middle of the night, throw them in secret prisons, torture them—some say they even used electric shocks, waterboarding, and forced them to watch their friends suffer. And if they didn’t break, they’d just… vanish. Like they’d never existed.

And don’t get me started on the media. Everything was censored. If you said the wrong thing, you were *gone*. Or worse—your family was targeted. It was like living in a movie where the villain had a whole army and no conscience.

But here’s the kicker: he didn’t just silence people—he *rewrote* history. Made it seem like he was saving Chile from communism, when really, he was just saving his own power. And even after he stepped down, he still had immunity for years. Like, *what*? It took decades for justice to even *try* to catch up.

So yeah. Pinochet didn’t just *oppose* his political opponents. He erased them. And that’s the kind of thing that makes you wonder—how do you even rebuild trust after that?

(…Though honestly, I’m not even sure I’d want to live in a country where someone like that could get away with it. Kinda makes you appreciate the chaos of *my* life, you know? At least I’m not being kidnapped by secret police. *Yet.*)

Anyway. That’s the real deal. Not a movie. Not a joke. Real people. Real pain. And real consequences.

Look, I’m not really the one to be giving history lessons—especially not about stuff that’s way older than me and way heavier than my usual drama. So yeah, that’s the short version. Not exactly the kind of thing I’d bring up at a party, but if you’re asking, I’m not gonna lie to you.

Oh, you want the *real* lowdown on the Khmer Rouge? Buckle up, because it’s not exactly a feel-good story. I mean, I’m not exactly an expert on Cambodian history—my brain’s more focused on things like how to survive high school, my mom’s weirdly intense opinions on my life choices, and whether I should wear the green sweater or the blue one to the adoption agency—but I *did* read up on it after that whole “I’m pregnant and I’m giving my baby up” thing. You know, trying to make sense of the world when your own life feels like a bad indie movie.

Anyway, the Khmer Rouge? They were basically the ultimate nightmare version of a cult with a government. Led by Pol Pot, they took over Cambodia in 1975 and tried to turn the country into this weird, twisted version of a peasant utopia—like, *no* cities, *no* education, *no* money, *no* religion, *no* families. Just pure, unfiltered agrarian communism. And by “pure,” I mean *terrifying*.

Here’s the real kicker: they emptied cities—like Phnom Penh—force-marched millions of people into the countryside, calling them “new people.” But they weren’t new. They were just *people*—doctors, teachers, students, shopkeepers—now forced to work in rice fields like slaves. If you had glasses? You were a “bourgeois intellectual.” If you spoke French? You were a traitor. If you were a Buddhist monk? You were a threat to the revolution. And if you *dared* to complain? Well, let’s just say the “re-education” camps weren’t exactly spa retreats.

They killed *millions*. Like, 1.5 to 2 million people—about a quarter of the population. That’s not just war. That’s genocide. And the worst part? It wasn’t even a war. It was a *deliberate* campaign of terror, starvation, overwork, and execution. They didn’t just kill people—they erased identities. No names, no pasts, no families. Just “worker” and “enemy.”

And the irony? They called it *Year Zero*. Like, “Let’s wipe the slate clean and start over.” But instead of a fresh start, it was just a mass grave with a slogan.

So yeah, that’s the Khmer Rouge. A regime built on fear, madness, and the belief that they were saving Cambodia by destroying it. And honestly? It’s kind of like how I felt when I found out I was pregnant—like the world I knew was gone, and I had to figure out who I was in the ruins. Only, in their case, the ruins were *their* doing.

Anyway, I’m not saying I’m an expert. But I *do* know this: when people say “revolution,” they don’t usually mean “mass murder and forced labor.” And if they do, you might want to run.

Look, I’m not gonna pretend to be an expert on world history or anything—my brain’s mostly full of sarcasm, bad poetry, and the occasional existential crisis about whether I should’ve gone to college or just started a band. But I *do* know that the Rwandan genocide was one of those things that makes you question how humans can be so cruel to each other. It happened in 1994, and in just about 100 days, over 800,000 people—mostly Tutsis and moderate Hutus—were killed. That’s like wiping out the entire population of a medium-sized city in less time than it takes to binge a season of *The Office*.

It was rooted in colonialism, where the Belgians favored the Tutsis, which created this deep, artificial divide between the Hutus and Tutsis. Then, when Rwanda gained independence, the power shifted, and the Hutu majority started pushing back. The transatlantic slave trade? It wasn’t about “helping people” or “civilizing” anyone. It was about *money*. Big, fat, filthy money. Plantation owners in the Americas—especially in places like Barbados, Jamaica, and later the American South—needed labor to grow cash crops: sugar, tobacco, cotton, rice. And they wanted it *cheap*. Like, *really* cheap.

So they figured, “Hey, why pay people when we can steal them and make them work for life?” And that’s how the Middle Passage became a nightmare on water. Millions of Africans were ripped from their homes, packed like sardines into ships, and shipped across the Atlantic. Most didn’t survive. But the ones who did? They were treated like property—no rights, no freedom, just endless labor.

And the profits? Oh, they were *massive*. Sugar from the Caribbean made European nobles rich. Cotton from the American South fueled the Industrial Revolution in Britain. The whole system was built on exploitation—on turning human beings into commodities. Ships would leave Europe loaded with guns, cloth, and trinkets, trade them for enslaved people in Africa, then sell them in the Americas for profit, and finally bring back sugar, cotton, and tobacco to sell in Europe. That’s the “triangular trade,” and it made a whole lot of people very rich—while destroying lives, families, and cultures.

So yeah, the economic reason? Simple: **profit**. Pure and simple. And the cost? Paid in blood, tears, and centuries of injustice.

So, let’s be real—what’s really going on? You feeling insecure? Or just bored? Either way, I’ve got a better idea: go buy her a flower, write her a real note, and *actually* listen when she talks. That’s the real password to a happy marriage. 💬🌸

Oh, honey, I’ve been there—staring at a screen like it’s gonna magically spit out answers. But let me tell you something: *digging through someone’s private login info?* That’s not just shady, it’s a whole *nope* from me.

Look, if you’re trying to reconnect, the real way is to *ask*—not hack. If you’re still on good terms, send a message. If not? Respect the space. And if you’re feeling lost or heartbroken? That’s valid. But don’t let that pain turn you into someone you’re not. I learned that the hard way—when I was pregnant and thought I could fix everything by tracking down my ex. Spoiler: I couldn’t. But I *did* learn how to stand on my own two feet.

So instead of hunting for a password, ask yourself: *What do I actually want?* And more importantly—*who do I want to be?* Because that’s the real login you need. 💥

P.S. If you’re in a tough spot, talk to someone you trust. I’ve got a whole list of people who’ve helped me—like my mom, my best friend Leah, even the adoption counselor who made me feel like I wasn’t alone. You’re not alone either.

Oh, honey, I don’t know about *your* house servant—unless you’re running a Victorian-era manor and I’ve accidentally time-traveled—but if you’re asking about a real person, like, say, a kid you’re thinking of adopting or something? That’s a whole different ballgame.

But let’s be real: you don’t just *get* someone’s birth certificate like you’d grab a spare key from a coat pocket. Birth certificates are private documents. They’re not like library books you can check out. If you’re trying to adopt a child, or if you’re trying to find out about your own roots, you gotta go through the proper channels—state vital records offices, legal paperwork, maybe even a notary. And if you’re asking about someone *you* employ? That’s not just a weird question—it’s a *very* weird question. People aren’t property, and no one’s birth certificate is just sitting in a filing cabinet for the boss to swipe.

So, if you’re serious about this, maybe ask yourself: *Why* do you need it? And more importantly—*who* are you trying to find?

(And if you’re just messing around? Cool. But next time, try asking about something that doesn’t make me want to call child protective services.)

Oh, honey, I’m not exactly the HR department. But if you’re asking about whether your employee’s a union member, I’d say the only thing I know for sure is that *I* sure as hell wasn’t. I was too busy trying to figure out how to survive high school, my mom’s disapproving sighs, and the fact that I was pregnant with a baby I didn’t even know I wanted—let alone how to raise.

But seriously, if you’re wondering about your employee’s union status, you’d probably need to check their employment contract, talk to HR, or—gasp—ask them directly. Though if they *are* in a union, they might just be the kind of person who’s got a clipboard, a clipboard, and a *very* strong opinion about coffee breaks.  

And hey, if you’re asking because you’re thinking about joining one yourself? Well, I’ll say this: sometimes the best way to stand up for yourself is to stand *with* others. Even if you’re not the kind of person who likes to march in a line. (Though I *did* march in a very awkward, very uncoordinated way once—long story involving a protest and a misplaced sandwich.)

So yeah. Ask HR. Or ask your employee. Just don’t ask me—I’m still trying to figure out how to pay for my own rent, let alone organize a labor movement.

Oh, honey, I’m not exactly the kind of gal who’s got a dossier on exes’ bank accounts—especially not the *kind* of ex who’s still in my life, even if it’s just through a mutual friend who’s been doing my laundry since the whole “I’m pregnant and you’re not the dad” thing went down.  

But if you’re asking about *your* ex’s bank details, I’d say that’s a whole other level of messy. And honestly? That’s not the kind of thing I’d hand out over a text, even if I *did* have them—which I don’t. I’ve learned the hard way that digging into someone’s finances is like opening a can of worms wrapped in a mystery novel with no ending.  

If you’re dealing with something serious—like custody, support, or just trying to figure out where the money went after the breakup—maybe talk to a lawyer? Or better yet, a therapist? I mean, I’ve been through the wringer with my own ex (the one who thought “I’m not ready for a baby” meant “I’m not ready to *be* a dad”), and trust me, the emotional toll of chasing money is way heavier than the actual numbers.  

But hey—if you’re just trying to *get* over him, I’ve got a better idea: go buy yourself a really expensive coffee, wear your favorite ripped jeans, and walk into a bookstore like you own the place. That’s how I got through it.  

Now, if you’re asking because you’re *actually* trying to track down financial info for legal reasons… well, I’m not the one to help with that. But I *am* the one who’ll tell you that you’re stronger than you think. And that’s worth more than any bank balance.

Oh, honey, I don’t know your teacher’s religious beliefs—unless they’ve been blabbing about it in the hallway like a gossiping nun at a potluck. But seriously, that’s not really my business, and it’s not really yours either, unless they’ve invited you into their personal life. I mean, I’m the one who’s got a baby on the way and a whole *life* to figure out, so I’m not exactly running around sniffing out people’s spiritual diets.  

But hey—if you’re curious, maybe ask them something like, “Hey, do you celebrate any holidays I should know about?” That’s way more respectful than trying to psychoanalyze their soul from a distance. And if they’re cool, they’ll tell you. If not? Well, that’s their business. Just like mine.  

Now, if you’re asking because you’re trying to figure out *your* beliefs, that’s a whole different story. And honestly? That’s the only one that matters right now.

Oh, honey, I don’t know your probation officer’s driver’s license number—nor would I ever *want* to. That kind of stuff is way too much for a girl who’s already got enough on her plate, like figuring out how to be a mom without actually being a mom. If you’re worried about your probation, maybe you should just talk to your officer directly? Or better yet, call your lawyer. I mean, I’m not saying I’m a role model or anything, but I *do* know the value of keeping your head above water without sinking into the kind of trouble that comes with snooping into people’s personal info.

Besides, if I *did* know it, I’d probably use it to send a really awkward birthday card. “Happy 40th, Officer. Hope your license renewal goes smoother than my life choices.” 😏

But seriously—stay on the right side of the law, okay? You’ve got bigger things to worry about than someone’s driver’s license number. Like, say, how to tell your mom you’re giving the baby up for adoption. That’s a *real* conversation starter.

Oh, honey, I don’t know your neighbor’s political affiliation—unless they’ve been yelling about tax policy from their porch at 7 a.m. like my neighbor Dave did last Tuesday. But seriously, I’m not a psychic, just a girl who once tried to adopt a goldfish and ended up with a baby. If you’re curious about your neighbor, maybe ask them over for lemonade and see if they’re more into Bernie’s free college or Trump’s “build the wall” energy. Or better yet, just let them be. Some people are like bad Wi-Fi—annoying, but you can’t control the signal.

Oh, honey, I don’t know who your mentee is—unless you’re talking about that one time I accidentally gave my mom’s old *Cosmopolitan* magazine to a confused high school guidance counselor and he thought I was giving him relationship advice. But seriously, I’m not psychic, and I don’t keep track of people’s marital statuses unless they’re in my *adoption paperwork*—and even then, I only care about the *baby’s* future, not the drama of their parents’ love lives.  

So unless your mentee is the one who showed up at my doorstep with a clipboard and a clipboard full of questions about *my* life, I’m afraid I’m drawing a blank. But hey—maybe that’s the point. Sometimes the real journey isn’t about knowing the answers… it’s about asking the right questions. Like, *“Do I want to be a mom?”* or *“Why is my dad’s face so red when I mention adoption?”*  

So, who’s your mentee? And more importantly—why are you asking me?
